name: Hsiang–Lawson's conjecture
rephrased: The only minimal surface that can be embedded as a torus in the 3-sphere S3 is the Clifford torus.
implication_form: If a torus is minimally embedded in S3, then it is the Clifford torus.
explained: Hsiang–Lawson's conjecture, originally attributed to Hsiang and later refined by Lawson, states that among all isometric embeddings of the flat torus into the 3-sphere S^3, only the Clifford torus is minimal (i.e., has mean curvature zero everywhere). A minimal surface is one that locally minimizes its area, and the mean curvature being zero is a stronger condition than just having zero mean curvature in the sense of harmonic maps for surfaces. The Clifford torus is defined as T_c = S^1(r) × S^1(√(2-r^2)) for some radius r (specifically, it is often taken with equal radii, though this is a special case). The conjecture asserts that this specific embedding is the unique one without singularities that minimizes surface area among all such embeddings.
related_conjectures: Isoparametric Hypothesis (concerning isoparametric hypersurfaces, where minimal tori are examples)
Willmore Conjecture (which concerns the Willmore energy of embedded tori in spheres, including S^3)
